title: Microsoft Embraces Google’s AI Agent Communication Protocol for Cross-Platform Collaboration
summary: Microsoft says that it’s embracing Google’s recently launched open protocol for allowing AI “agents” to communicate with each other. On Wednesday, Microsoft announced that it would bring support for Google’s Agent2Agent (A2A) spec to two of its AI development platforms, Azure AI Foundry and Copilot Studio. Microsoft has also joined the A2A working group on […]
full_text_content:
Microsoft says that it’s embracing Google’s recently launched open protocol for allowing AI “agents” to communicate with each other.
On Wednesday, Microsoft announced that it would bring support for Google’s Agent2Agent (A2A) spec to two of its AI development platforms, Azure AI Foundry and Copilot Studio. Microsoft has also joined the A2A working group on GitHub to contribute to the protocol and tooling.
“By supporting A2A and building on our open orchestration platform, we’re laying the foundation for the next generation of software — collaborative, observable, and adaptive by design,” wrote the company in a blog post. “The best agents won’t live in one app or cloud; they’ll operate in the flow of work, spanning models, domains, and ecosystems.”
A2A, which Google unveiled in early April, allows agents — AI-powered semi-autonomous programs — to work together across different clouds, apps, and services. Using the protocol, agents can exchange goals and invoke actions. Developers get a set of interoperable components they can use to make sure agent collaboration occurs securely.
Once A2A support arrives for Azure AI Foundry and Copilot Studio, agents built using the platforms will be able to tap external agents for tasks, including agents created with other tools or hosted outside Microsoft. For example, a Microsoft agent could schedule a meeting while a Google agent drafts the email invites.
“[C]ustomers can build complex, multi-agent workflows that span internal [agents], partner tools, and production infrastructure — while maintaining governance and service-level agreements,” the company explained in its blog post. “We’re aligning with the broader industry push for shared agent protocols.”
While it’s far from perfect, agentic technology is attracting increasing investment as enterprises look to adopt it to boost productivity. According to a recent KPMG survey, 65% of companies are experimenting with AI agents. Markets and Markets projects that the AI agent segment will grow from $7.84 billion in 2025 to $52.62 billion by 2030.
Exhibit at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
Exhibit at TechCrunch Sessions: AI
Microsoft’s decision to throw its weight behind A2A comes after the company introduced support for MCP, Anthropic’s standard for connecting AI to the systems where data resides, in Copilot Studio. Other major AI model providers, including Google and OpenAI, announced that they would adopt MCP earlier this year.

seo_agent_results.generated_article_body_md:
## Microsoft Embraces Google’s AI Agent Communication Protocol for Cross-Platform Collaboration Microsoft has announced its adoption of Google’s **AI agent communication protocol**, Agent2Agent (A2A), integrating it into Azure AI Foundry and Copilot Studio. This move enables AI agents built on Microsoft’s platforms to interact seamlessly with external agents, including those hosted on Google’s ecosystem. By joining the A2A working group, Microsoft aims to foster a collaborative, interoperable AI landscape where agents can securely exchange goals and execute tasks across different clouds and applications. ### Unpacking the Impact of A2A Integration The adoption of A2A marks a significant step toward standardizing **AI agent communication protocols** in the industry. Microsoft’s support for A2A allows developers to create multi-agent workflows that span internal systems, partner tools, and third-party services while maintaining governance and security. For example, a Microsoft AI agent could schedule a meeting while a Google agent drafts the invitation—showcasing the potential for seamless cross-platform automation. This aligns with broader industry efforts to establish shared agent protocols, following Microsoft’s earlier adoption of Anthropic’s MCP standard. With enterprises increasingly experimenting with AI agents—65% according to a KPMG survey—interoperability is becoming critical. The AI agent market is projected to grow from $7.84 billion in 2025 to $52.62 billion by 2030, underscoring the importance of standardized communication frameworks. #### The Technology Behind A2A Google’s A2A protocol enables AI agents to work together across different environments by providing a set of interoperable components. Agents can securely exchange objectives and invoke actions, ensuring smooth collaboration. Microsoft’s integration means Azure AI and Copilot Studio users can now leverage external agents for complex workflows, enhancing productivity and flexibility. #### Pros & Cons
Pros
- **Enhanced interoperability** between Microsoft and Google AI ecosystems. - **Secure, standardized communication** for multi-agent workflows. - **Increased productivity** through seamless cross-platform automation.
Cons
- **Early-stage technology** with potential unforeseen limitations. - **Dependence on third-party protocols** may introduce compatibility risks.
#### Frequently Asked Questions
What is the A2A protocol?

A2A (Agent2Agent) is Google’s open protocol enabling AI agents to communicate and collaborate across different platforms and services securely.

How does Microsoft’s adoption of A2A benefit developers?

Developers can now build AI agents in Azure AI and Copilot Studio that interact with external agents, expanding workflow possibilities and improving automation.
